content: "Any soldier who goes into battle against the Taliban in pink boxers and flip-flops has a special kind of courage," Gates said, adding that Boyd may have hit on a new kind of psychological warfare. "I can only wonder about the impact on the Taliban. Just imagine seeing that - a guy in pink boxers and flip-flops has you in his crosshairs." BWaaahaaahaaaaaa! Gates is one CLASSY leader! Don't F with us, Hadji. We have boxers! Best story... eva! It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: I read the FULL article in the local paper (Arizona Daily Star), as well as on my Home Page...the edited MilCom didn't give the whole side. Does the phrase: "Adapt, Improvise and Overcome" come to mind? You nay-sayers should get a grip and appreciate the overall humor of the picture and associated FULL article behind it. The picture and FULL article has brought a bit of humor and the human side of this war...and onehelluva morale boosting laugh to it all. This adds to the venerable "Kilroy Wuz Here" cartoon to a higher element!

content: After weeks of speculation, the Army put the rumors to rest when a soldier stepped out in the replacement BDUs. The choice by the 25 year old soldier up-and-commer stunned some critics in the GI fashion community who had predicted that the soldiers would wear bright colors and a more modern silhouette, more revealing that the standard issue utilized here-to-fore by all branches of the military. “It was a little bit of a disappointment,” groaned SFC Verdi. “A more revealing design would had been more preferable.” The Army scored points for frugality during a recession with the new replacement, BDUs. This is a “greener Army who operates more in the red,” commented Army fashion spokesman, Major Stephen Galanos. “Still the choice is far from a fashion disaster.”
reply: After weeks of speculation, the Army put the rumors to rest when a soldier stepped out in the replacement BDUs.
